queyu_utils.pytorch.model module¶

Utils for pytorch model.

class queyu_utils.pytorch.model.ModelSaveMethod(value)¶

Bases: enum.Enum

Methods to save pytorch model.

FULL = 1¶

Save full model.

JIT = 2¶

Save model after JIT trace.

WEIGHT = 0¶

Save the weight (state_dict) of model.

class queyu_utils.pytorch.model.ModuleActivationCapture(module)¶

Bases: object

Util for capturing input / output feature map of target module in pytorch model after inferring.

Examples

>>> from torchvision.models import resnet18
>>> model = resnet18()
>>> # intend to get the input/output feature map of the first conv layer of first ResBlock in ResNet18
>>> module_activation_capture = ModuleActivationCapture(get_module(model, 'layer1.0.conv1'), 'cuda')
>>> # let model perform inference...
>>> # get the input/output feature map created during last inference
>>> module_input, module_output = module_activation_capture.input, module_activation_capture.output
>>> # remove hook to avoid performance waste
>>> module_activation_capture.remove()
Parameters

module (Module) – Target module.

input¶

Store the input feature map of target module created during last inference. Before first inference it’s None.

Type

Optional[torch.Tensor]

output¶

Store the output feature map of target module created during last inference. Before first inference it’s None.

Type

Optional[torch.Tensor]

remove()¶

Remove the hook after getting the input/output.

class queyu_utils.pytorch.model.ModuleActivationCaptureWrapper(mac_list)¶

Bases: object

Util for capturing input / output feature map of a series of modules in pytorch model after inferring.

Examples

>>> from torchvision.models import resnet18
>>> model = resnet18()
>>> # intend to get the input feature map of the first conv layer and
>>> # the output feature map of the first bn layer of first ResBlock in ResNet18
>>> # i.e. regard (layer1.0.conv1, layer1.0.bn1) as a (hyper-) module
>>> module_activation_capture_wrapper = ModuleActivationCaptureWrapper([
>>>    ModuleActivationCapture(get_module(model, 'layer1.0.conv1'), 'cuda'),
>>>    ModuleActivationCapture(get_module(model, 'layer1.0.bn1'), 'cuda'),
>>> ])
>>> # let model perform inference...
>>> # get the input/output feature map created during last inference
>>> module_input = module_activation_capture_wrapper.input
>>> module_output = module_activation_capture_wrapper.output
>>> # remove hook to avoid performance waste
>>> module_activation_capture_wrapper.remove()
Parameters

mac_list (List[ModuleActivationCapture]) – A series of ModuleActivationCapture which belong to a series of modules.

property input¶

Store the input feature map of first module created during last inference. Before first inference it’s None.

Return type

Optional[Tensor]

property output¶

Store the output feature map of last module created during last inference. Before first inference it’s None.

Return type

Optional[Tensor]

remove()¶

Remove the hooks after getting the input/output.

class queyu_utils.pytorch.model.ModuleLatencyProfiler(module)¶

Bases: object

Util for profiling module latency (inference time) in pytorch model during inferring.

Examples

>>> from torchvision.models import resnet18
>>> model = resnet18()
>>> # intend to get latency of the first conv layer of first ResBlock in ResNet18
>>> module_latency_profiler = ModuleLatencyProfiler(get_module(model, 'layer1.0.conv1'))
>>> # let model perform inference...
>>> # get the latency measured during last inference
>>> module_latency = module_latency_profiler.latency
>>> # remove hook to avoid performance waste
>>> module_latency_profiler.remove()
Parameters

module (Module) – Target module.

latency¶

Store the latency value of target module created during last inference. Before first inference it’s None.

Type

Optional[float]

remove()¶

Remove the hook after getting the input/output.

class queyu_utils.pytorch.model.ModuleLatencyProfilerWrapper(mlp_list)¶

Bases: object

Util for profiling latency of a series of modules in pytorch model during inferring.

Examples

>>> from torchvision.models import resnet18
>>> model = resnet18()
>>> # intend to get total latency of the first conv layer and
>>> # the first bn layer of first ResBlock in ResNet18
>>> # i.e. regard (layer1.0.conv1, layer1.0.bn1) as a (hyper-) module
>>> module_latency_profiler_wrapper = ModuleLatencyProfilerWrapper([
>>>    ModuleLatencyProfiler(get_module(model, 'layer1.0.conv1')),
>>>    ModuleLatencyProfiler(get_module(model, 'layer1.0.bn1')),
>>> ])
>>> # let model perform inference...
>>> # get the total latency measured during last inference
>>> module_input = module_latency_profiler_wrapper.latency
>>> # remove hook to avoid performance waste
>>> module_latency_profiler_wrapper.remove()
Parameters

mlp_list (List[ModuleLatencyProfiler]) – A series of ModuleLatencyProfiler which belong to a series of modules.

property latency¶

Store the total latency value of target modules created during last inference. Before first inference it’s None.

remove()¶

Remove the hooks after getting the input/output.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.get_ith_layer(model, i)¶

Get i-th layer of pytorch model.

Examples

>>> from torchvision.models import resnet18
>>> model = resnet18()
>>> get_ith_layer(model, 3)
MaxPool2d(kernel_size=3, stride=2, padding=1, dilation=1, ceil_mode=False)
Parameters

  • model (Module) – A pytorch model.

  • i (int) – The index of target layer in model.

Return type

Optional[Module]

Returns

i-th layer of model.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.get_model_flops_and_params(model, input_size)¶

Get FLOPs and number of parameters of pytorch model.

Parameters

  • model (Module) – A pytorch model.

  • input_size (Tuple[int]) – The size of input data of model.

Return type

Tuple[int, int]

Returns

FLOPs and number of parameters of the model.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.get_model_latency(model, input_size, sample_num, device, warmup=True, return_detail=False)¶

Get the latency (inference time) of pytorch model.

Examples

>>> from torchvision.models import resnet18
>>> model = resnet18()
>>> get_model_latency(model, (1, 3, 224, 224), 10, 'cuda', warmup=True, return_detail=False)
0.158232
>>> get_model_latency(model, (1, 3, 224, 224), 10, 'cuda', warmup=True, return_detail=True)
(0.158232, [0.152312, 0.162301, ...])
Parameters

  • model (Module) – A pytorch model.

  • input_size (Tuple[int, …]) – The size of input data of model.

  • sample_num (int) – The number of dummy input for testing.

  • device (str) – Target device for testing.

  • warmup (bool) – Whether inferring several dummy samples to warm for more accurate result. Defaults to True.

  • return_detail (bool) – If True, return all latency info during testing too, i.e. (avg_latency, latency_list), or return average latency only. Defaults to False.

Return type

Union[float, Tuple[float, List[float]]]

Returns

If return_detail is True, return all latency info during testing too, i.e. (avg_latency, latency_list), or return average latency only.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.get_model_size(model)¶

Get the file size of pytorch model.

Parameters

model (Module) – A pytorch model.

Return type

int

Returns

The file size of the model.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.get_module(model, module_name)¶

Get target module from a pytorch model.

Examples

>>> from torchvision.models import resnet18
>>> model = resnet18()
>>> get_module(model, 'layer1.0.conv1')
Conv2d(64, 64, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1), bias=False)
Parameters

  • model (Module) – A pytorch model.

  • module_name (str) – Target module name, which can be previewed by calling model.named_modules() in pytorch.

Return type

Optional[Module]

Returns

Target module from model. If it doesn’t exist, return None.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.get_module_conv_layers_name(module)¶

Get the name list of all convolution layers in pytorch module.

Parameters

module (Module) – Target module.

Return type

List[str]

Returns

The name list of all convolution layers in the module.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.get_super_module(model, module_name)¶

Get super module of target module from a pytorch model.

Examples

>>> from torchvision.models import resnet18
>>> model = resnet18()
>>> get_super_module(model, 'layer1.0.conv1')
BasicBlock(
  (conv1): Conv2d(64, 64, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1), bias=False)
  (bn1): BatchNorm2d(64, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
  (relu): ReLU(inplace=True)
  (conv2): Conv2d(64, 64, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1), bias=False)
  (bn2): BatchNorm2d(64, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
)
Parameters

  • model (Module) – A pytorch model.

  • module_name (str) – Target module name, which can be previewed by calling model.named_modules() in pytorch.

Return type

Optional[Module]

Returns

Super module of target module from model. If it doesn’t exist, return None.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.load_model(model_file_path, save_method, device)¶

Load pytorch model from disk.

Parameters

  • model_file_path (str) – File path of a pytorch model.

  • save_method (ModelSaveMethod) – The method to save model.

  • device (str) – Target device for loaded model.

Return type

Union[dict, Module]

Returns

loaded model.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.save_model(model, model_file_path, input_size=None, save_method=<ModelSaveMethod.WEIGHT: 0>)¶

Save pytorch model.

Parameters

  • model (Module) – A pytorch model.

  • model_file_path (str) – Target model file path.

  • input_size (Optional[Tuple[int, …]]) – The size of input data of model. Defaults to None.

  • save_method (ModelSaveMethod) – The method to save model. Defaults to ModelSaveMethod.WEIGHT.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.set_ith_layer(model, i, layer)¶

Replace i-th layer of pytorch model with new layer.

Parameters

  • model (Module) – A pytorch model.

  • i (int) – The index of target layer in model.

  • layer (Module) – New layer which will be replaced into model.

queyu_utils.pytorch.model.set_module(model, module_name, module)¶

Replace target module with new module in a pytorch model.

Parameters

  • model (Module) – A pytorch model.

  • module_name – Target module name, which can be previewed by calling model.named_modules() in pytorch.

  • module (Module) – Module which will be replaced into model.
